name: Cuban Music
description: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

children.name: Abakuá Music
children.description: Ritual music associated with the Abakuá religious fraternity of Cuba, descending from the Ékpè tradition of West Africa.

children.name: Abakuá Music
children.description: Ritual music associated with the Abakuá religious fraternity of Cuba, descending from the Ékpè tradition of West Africa.

children.name: Chachachá
children.description: Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.

children.name: Chachachá
children.description: Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.

children.name: Changüí
children.description: One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.

children.name: Changüí
children.description: One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.

children.name: Conga
children.description: Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.

children.name: Conga
children.description: Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.

children.name: Cuban Charanga
children.description: Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.

children.name: Cuban Charanga
children.description: Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.

children.name: Cubaton
children.description: Rhythmically and vocally inspired by major elements of Cuban Music.

children.name: Cubaton
children.description: Rhythmically and vocally inspired by major elements of Cuban Music.

children.name: Danzón
children.description: Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

children.name: Danzón
children.description: Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

children.name: Descarga
children.description: Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.

children.name: Descarga
children.description: Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.

children.name: Filin
children.description: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.

children.name: Filin
children.description: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.

children.name: Guajira
children.description: Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.

children.name: Guajira
children.description: Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.

children.name: Guaracha
children.description: Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.

children.name: Guaracha
children.description: Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.

children.name: Habanera
children.description: Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.

children.name: Habanera
children.description: Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.

children.name: Mambo
children.description: Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.

children.name: Mambo
children.description: Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.

children.name: Mozambique
children.description: Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.

children.name: Mozambique
children.description: Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.

children.name: Pachanga
children.description: Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.

children.name: Pachanga
children.description: Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.

children.name: Pilón
children.description: Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.

children.name: Pilón
children.description: Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.

children.name: Rumba cubana
children.description: Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.

children.name: Rumba cubana
children.description: Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.

children.name: Santería Music
children.description: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

children.name: Santería Music
children.description: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

children.name: Son cubano
children.description: Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.

children.name: Son cubano
children.description: Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.

children.name: Songo
children.description: Cuban style originating in the late 1960s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.

children.name: Songo
children.description: Cuban style originating in the late 1960s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.

children.name: Timba
children.description: Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.

children.name: Timba
children.description: Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.

children.name: Trova
children.description: One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone Singer-Songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.

children.name: Trova
children.description: One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone Singer-Songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.

children.name: Tumba francesa
children.description: Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.

children.name: Tumba francesa
children.description: Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.
